metadata.titleEn: ChinaHighSO2: High-resolution and High-quality Ground-level SO2 Dataset for China (2013-2023)
metadata.description: ChinaHighSO2 is one of the series of long-term, full-coverage, high-resolution, and high-quality datasets of ground-level air pollutants for China (i.e., ChinaHighAirPollutants, CHAP). It is generated from the big data (e.g., ground-based measurements, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations) using artificial intelligence by considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This is the big data-derived seamless (spatial coverage = 100%) daily, monthly, and yearly 1 km (i.e., D1K, M1K, and Y1K) ground-level SO2 dataset in China from 2013 to present. Note that this dataset is 10 km before 2019, and improved to 1 km after 2019. This dataset yields a high quality with a cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) value of of 0.84 and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 10.07 µg m-3 for the daily retrievals, respectively. Note that this dataset is continuously updated, and if you want to apply for more data or have any questions, please contact me (Email: weijing_rs@163.com; weijing@umd.edu). The data file contains four codes (Python, Matlab, IDL and R language) nc2geotiff codes for NC to GeoTiff.
metadata.instructions: File Name: The data is stored in the NetCDF file format, and the file name is CHAP_SO2_ab_yyyymmdd_V1.nc, where a represents time resolution (D represents daily data, M represents monthly data, Y represents annual data), b represents spatial resolution (1K represents 1km), yyyy represents year, mm represents month, and dd represents day. Data reading method: Python, Matlab, IDL, and other programming methods can be used to convert files from NC to TIF. The data coordinate system is WGS-1984, with a background value of 65535.

literatureList.titleEn: Ground-level gaseous pollutants (NO2, SO2, and CO) in China: daily seamless mapping and spatiotemporal variations
literatureList.referenceEn: Wei, J., Li, Z., Wang, J., Li, C., Gupta, P., & Cribb, M. (2023). Ground-level gaseous pollutants (NO2, SO2, and CO) in China: daily seamless mapping and spatiotemporal variations. Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, 23, 1511–1532. https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-23-1511-2023

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main features and specifications of a dataset that utilizes artificial intelligence for high-resolution, high-quality ground-level SO2 data collection in China from 2013 to the present?
Feature Specification.Answer: spatio-temporal heterogeneity, big data sources, cross-validation R2 of 0.84, RMSE of 10.07 µg/m3, spatial resolution of 10 km prior to 2019, spatial resolution of 1 km post-2019, temporal resolution includes daily, monthly, and yearly data, measured in µg/m3

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution in kilometers of a dataset on near-surface SO2 levels in China before 2019?

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of a dataset with 10 km resolution before 2019 compare to one with 1 km resolution after 2019 in terms of capturing spatial heterogeneity of ground-level SO2 across China?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial resolution of 10 km before 2019 is coarser compared to the 1 km resolution after 2019. The finer 1 km resolution is likely to capture spatial heterogeneity of ground-level SO2 across China more accurately, providing more detailed insights into local variations in pollution levels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons for employing artificial intelligence techniques in the data collection process of high-resolution ground-level SO2 datasets in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Artificial intelligence techniques are employed to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution and to process large-scale data from various sources such as ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations, ensuring the production of seamless ground-level SO2 data across China.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of employing artificial intelligence techniques in creating a dataset for high-resolution SO2 measurements across China from 2013 to 2023?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of artificial intelligence techniques aims to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution and to produce a seamless, high-resolution dataset of ground-level SO2 measurements across China. This is achieved by integrating data from various large-scale sources such as ground observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to integrate various data sources, such as satellite remote sensing products and atmospheric reanalysis, to produce high-resolution ground-level SO2 datasets in China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To produce high-resolution ground-level SO2 datasets in China, artificial intelligence techniques are utilized to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This involves integrating big data sources like ground observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data, ensuring a seamless nationwide dataset from 2013 to the present.
